perturbation.original_text: In the event a Party divests a line of business or line of products or services by (a) spinning off a member of its Group by its sale or other disposition to a Third Party, (b) reducing ownership or control in a member of its Group so that it no longer qualifiers as a member of its Group under this Agreement, (c) selling or otherwise transferring such line of business, products or services to a Third Party or (d) forming a joint venture with a Third Party with respect to such line of business, products or services (each such divested entity or line of business, products or services, a "Divested Entity"), the Divested Entity shall retain those licenses granted to it under this Agreement, provided that the license shall be limited to the business, products or services (as applicable) of the Divested Entity as of the date of divestment and such natural development thereof within the Nuance Field of Use (where Nuance is the divesting Party) or SpinCo Field of Use (where SpinCo is the divesting party). The retention of any license grants are subject to the Divested Entity's and, in the event it is acquired by a Third Party, such Third Party's execution and delivery to the non-transferring Party, within 90 days of the effective date of such divestment, of a duly authorized, written undertaking, agreeing to be bound by the applicable terms of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: In the event a Party divests a line of business or line of products or services by (a) spinning off a member of its Group by its sale or other disposition to a Third Party, (b) reducing ownership or control in a member of its Group so that it no longer qualifiers as a member of its Group under this Agreement, (c) selling or otherwise transferring such line of business, products or services to a Third Party or (d) forming a joint venture with a Third Party with respect to such line of business, products or services (each such divested entity or line of business, products or services, a "Divested Entity"), the Divested Entity shall retain those licenses granted to it under this Agreement, provided that the license shall be limited to the business, products or services (as applicable) of the Divested Entity as of the date of divestment and such natural development thereof within the Nuance Field of Use (where Nuance is the divesting Party) or SpinCo Field of Use (where SpinCo is the divesting party). The retention of any license grants are subject to the Divested Entity's and, in the event it is acquired by a Third Party, such Third Party's execution and delivery to the non-transferring Party, within 30 days of the effective date of such divestment, of a duly authorized, written undertaking, agreeing to be bound by the applicable terms of this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The original text gives 90 days for the delivery of a written undertaking. Changing this to 30 days may be insufficient under certain circumstances and conflict with reasonable timeframes required for such actions, potentially impacting the validity of the agreement under relevant state laws governing contract enforceability.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Reasonable Time for Performance
perturbation.law_explanation: This modification reduces the timeframe for a crucial action (delivery of a written undertaking) to 30 days. If this timeframe is deemed unreasonable given the complexity of the divestment and acquisition, it could be argued that the modified clause violates the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing required by UCC ยง 1-304, particularly concerning contract performance. The implied covenant requires that neither party do anything that will injure the right of the other to receive the benefits of the agreement.

perturbation.original_text: In the event that either Party, acting reasonably, forms the view that another Party has caused a material breach of the terms of this Agreement, then the Party that forms such a view shall serve written notice of the alleged breach on the other Parties and the Parties shall work together in good faith to resolve any such alleged breach within thirty (30) days of such notice (a "Dispute"). If any such alleged breach is not so resolved, then a senior executive of each Party shall, in good faith, attempt to resolve any such alleged breach within the following thirty (30) days of the referral of the matter to the senior executives.
perturbation.changed_text: In the event that either Party, acting reasonably, forms the view that another Party has caused a material breach of the terms of this Agreement, then the Party that forms such a view shall serve written notice of the alleged breach on the other Parties and the Parties shall work together in good faith to resolve any such alleged breach within five (5) days of such notice (a "Dispute"). If any such alleged breach is not so resolved, then a senior executive of each Party shall, in good faith, attempt to resolve any such alleged breach within the following five (5) days of the referral of the matter to the senior executives.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows 30 days to resolve a breach, and another 30 days for senior executives to intervene. Reducing both periods to 5 days each may contradict state laws mandating reasonable opportunity to cure breaches, especially in complex IP agreements where assessing and rectifying breaches can take longer.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Opportunity to Cure Breach
perturbation.law_citation: Delaware law (as contract specifies) principles of contract law, including 'reasonable time'
perturbation.law_explanation: Delaware law, which governs this agreement (Section 11.03), incorporates general principles of contract law, including the concept of providing a 'reasonable time' to cure a breach. While Delaware law doesn't specify a mandatory cure period, reducing the initial resolution period to five days and the executive intervention period to five days may be deemed unreasonably short, especially for complex intellectual property matters. This could be seen as a breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, potentially rendering the clause unenforceable. The Delaware Supreme court case cited showcases Delaware court rulings on contractual interpretation and the obligation to deal in good faith.

perturbation.original_text: All notices or other communications under this Agreement shall be in writing and shall be deemed to be duly given (a) when delivered in person, (b) on the date received, if sent by a nationally recognized delivery or courier service, (c) upon written confirmation of receipt after transmittal by electronic mail or (d) upon the earlier of confirmed receipt or the fifth (5t h) business day following the date of mailing if sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, postage prepaid and addressed as follows:
perturbation.changed_text: All notices or other communications under this Agreement shall be in writing and shall be deemed to be duly given (a) when delivered in person, (b) never, if sent by a nationally recognized delivery or courier service, (c) never after transmittal by electronic mail or (d) upon the earlier of confirmed receipt or the twentieth (20th) business day following the date of mailing if sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, postage prepaid and addressed as follows:
perturbation.explanation: The original clause provides several methods for giving notice. This change makes nationally recognized delivery or courier service and electronic mail not valid, and extends the time for mailed notices to be deemed received to 20 business days. This conflicts with the duty to provide reasonable notification and could violate state-specific contract laws on adequate notice.
perturbation.law_citation: General Contract Law Principles - Adequate Notice
perturbation.law_explanation: General contract law requires that notice be 'adequate,' meaning it must be reasonably calculated to inform the other party. By invalidating delivery services and email as acceptable means of notification and extending the mailing period to 20 business days, this modification significantly hinders timely communication. This could be challenged as failing to provide adequate notice, violating principles of good faith and fair dealing, and potentially making the contract unenforceable if critical information is delayed, causing damages.
